The following discussion is largely based on Brynjolfsson et al
in-firm training still requires a base of educated manpower to work with, which can be provided only by general schooling

To avoid problems associated with conceptualizing skill, we use a rather broad definition suggested by Okada (2000: 10): Skills refer to the range of capabilities to apply and transfer knowledge into action in production processes in manufacturing, including managerial, organizational, and technical skills that individuals acquire through either schooling or on-the-job training
